At this occasion the skull of Jacob Frank was removed from the grave and, carefully described as “the skull of a Jewish patriarch”, ended up in the hands of an Offenbach historian. Many years later, in unknown circumstances, it arrived in Berlin, where it was subjected to detailed measurements and tests and declared to be an example of Jewish racial inferiority. After the war it disappeared without a trace – perhaps destroyed in the war chaos, turned to dust, or still lying in the underground storage of some museum.
rejectText: All Offenbach neophytes were buried in the city cemetery, which after many years began to interfere with the plans for the expansion of the city and was liquidated in 1866. The bones of the people buried there were collected and respectfully buried elsewhere. On this occasion, Jacob Frank's skull was removed from the grave and, carefully described as "the skull of the Jewish patriarch", found its way into the hands of the historiographer of the city of Offenbach. Many years later, in unknown circumstances, she ended up in Berlin, where she was subjected to detailed measurements and research and considered an example of Jewish racial inferiority. After the war, it disappeared without a trace - maybe it was destroyed by the turmoil of war, crumbled to dust, or it still lies in the underground warehouses of some museum.
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment: T1 is a bit too much of a word by word translation, T2 is much better stylewise. What I was missing in T2 was the indication that it was "after many year" that the cementery became a problem.

source: Najwięcej do powiedzenia byłoby o rodzinie Wołowskich, jako że rozrosła się do ogromnych rozmiarów. Niemal wszystkie gałęzie tego rodu zostały nobilitowane, jedne były herbu Bawół, drugie herbu Na Kaskach. Niewątpliwie wielką karierę zrobił Franciszek, syn Izaaka Wołowskiego, tego samego, którego ksiądz Chmielowski nazwał Jeremiaszem. Urodził się w 1786 roku w Brünn i wychowany w Offenbachu, stał się jednym z najlepszych prawników i znawcą prawa tamtego czasu. Co ciekawe – gdy w sejmie pojawił się wniosek o nadanie polskiego obywatelstwa Żydom, Franciszek jako poseł w swojej porywającej przemowie przekonywał, że jeszcze nie czas na taki krok. Najpierw naród polski musi wywalczyć sobie niepodległość, a potem będzie pora na reformy społeczne.
choiceText: The most to be said would be about the Wołowski family, as it had grown to immense proportions. Almost all the branches of this family had been ennobled, one with the Bawół coat of arms, the other with the Na Kaskach coat of arms. Undoubtedly, Franciszek, the son of Izaak Wołowski, the same one whom Father Chmielowski had called Jeremiah, had made a great career. He was born in 1786 in Brünn and raised in Offenbach, and became one of the best lawyers and legal experts of the time. Interestingly, when the motion to grant Polish citizenship to Jews was presented to the Sejm, Franciszek, as a member of parliament, argued in his passionate speech that it was not yet the time for such a step. First the Polish nation must win its independence, and then it will be time for social reforms.
rejectText: The most to say would be about the Wołowski family, as it has grown to enormous proportions. Almost all branches of this family were ennobled, some were of the Bawół coat of arms, others of the Na Kaskach coat of arms. Undoubtedly, Franciszek, the son of Izaak Wołowski, the same one whom Father Chmielowski called Jeremiah, made a great career. Born in 1786 in Brünn and brought up in Offenbach, he became one of the best lawyers and law experts of his time. Interestingly, when an application for granting Polish citizenship to Jews appeared in the Sejm, Franciszek, as an MP, argued in his spirited speech that it was not yet time for such a step. First, the Polish nation must win its independence, and then it will be time for social reforms.
difficult_choice: YES, both translations are close in quality and it was hard to choose between them.
comment: T1 is better stylewise and more natural (especially the first sentence). That said, both are of comparable quality.

source: Wyrastają przed nimi pierwsze zabudowania, nagle, bez ostrzeżenia. Widać mgła zmienia poczucie odległości, bo zaskoczona tym wydaje się sama Kaśka. Nagle skacze, szarpiąc dyszlem, i gdyby nie stanowcza reakcja Roszka i jego bat, wywróciłaby kolaskę. Może Kaśkę wystraszyły iskry, które sypią się z paleniska, albo niepokój koni czekających na swoją kolej do podkuwania...
choiceText: The first buildings start to appear before them, suddenly, without warning. The fog seems to distort the sense of distance, for Kasia seems taken aback by it. Suddenly she jumps, tugging at the reins, and if it weren’t for Roszek’s firm reaction and his whip, she would have overturned the carriage. Perhaps Kasia was scared by the sparks flying from the fire, or the unease of the horses waiting their turn to be shod. . .
rejectText: The first buildings sprout up in front of them, suddenly, without warning. Apparently the fog changes the sense of distance, because Kaśka herself seems surprised. Suddenly, he jumps, jerking the drawbar, and if not for Roszek's firm reaction and his whip, he would have overturned the cart. Maybe Kaśka was scared by the sparks that fall from the hearth, or the anxiety of the horses waiting for their turn to shoe...
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment: Translation 1 is much better style-wise and sounds more natural. There are some elements I like better in T2 (such as translation of dyszel as drawback and not as reins), but when it comes to style T2 is rather coarse and the flow isn't natural. Plus, T2 got the sex of the horse wrong ("he" vs "she") -- both "it" and "she" are acceptable in English, "he" is not.

source: Wszędzie czuć mdły zapach słodu, przenika każdy towar wystawiony do sprzedaży. Można się nim najeść jak chlebem. Na przedmieściach Rohatyna, w Babińcach, jest kilka małych browarów, to stamtąd roznosi się na całą okolicę ten sycący zapach. Wiele kramików sprzedaje tu piwo, a lepsze sklepy mają na składzie i gorzałkę, i miód pitny, głównie trójniak. Skład żydowskiego kupca Wakszula oferuje wino, prawdziwego węgrzyna i prawdziwe reńskie, i takie trochę kwaskowate, które przywożą tu aż z Wołoszczyzny.
choiceText: Everywhere you can smell the sickly smell of malt, permeates every product put up for sale. You can eat it like bread. In the suburbs of Rohatyn, in Babince, there are several small breweries, from there the filling smell spreads to the whole area. Many stalls sell beer here, and the better shops stock both vodka and mead, mainly Trójniak. The warehouse of the Jewish merchant Wakszul offers wine, real Hungarian and real Rhenish, and a little sour, which are brought here from Wallachia.
rejectText: The faint smell of malt pervades everything for sale. You could eat it like bread. In the suburbs of Rohatyn, in Babińce, there are a few small breweries, from which the nourishing aroma spreads across the whole area. Many stalls sell beer here, and the better shops have both moonshine and mead in stock, mainly three-grain. The Jewish merchant Wakszul’s store offers wine, real Hungarian and real Rhine, and some slightly sour stuff they bring all the way from Transylvania.
difficult_choice: YES, both translations are close in quality and it was hard to choose between them.
comment:
First of all, T1 got right the tiny annoying mistranslations that kept popping up in other translations (sycący is finally for once translated as filling in T1, and not nourishing as in other translations). Then, this is the closest translation of "mdły" that I've seen so far - considering the context it would be better to make it "sickly sweet" or "nauseating".
Now, I might be a bit biased because this is a smell that makes me sick, and one of meanings of the word "mdly" in Polish is faint, but to me the very nature of this smell and the fact that this is the secondary and not primary meaning of the word "mdły" makes me consider it a mistranslation. 

I indicated that both translations are close in quality because they fail at different aspects - style-wise T2 is better, when it comes to choice of words and content, T1 is better. So, weighted average would be similar, but in the end I went with T1.

source: De main en main passaient des photos brunies au dos taché par tous les doigts qui les avaient tenues dans d’autres repas, mélange de café et de graisse fondu en une couleur indéfinissable. Dans les mariés raides et graves, les invités de la noce s’étageant sur plusieurs rangs le long d’un mur, on ne reconnaissait ni ses parents ni personne. Ce n’était pas soi non plus qu’on voyait dans le bébé de sexe indistinct à demi nu sur un coussin mais quelqu’un d’autre, une créature appartenant à un temps muet et inaccessible.
choiceText: Photos, browned and stained on the back by the fingers of all those who had held them at other meals, passed from hand to hand. In the stiff and serious wedding-party, the guests arranged in several rows along a wall, one could not recognize either one's parents or anyone else. Nor was it oneself that one saw in the half-naked, sexless baby on a cushion, but someone else, a creature belonging to a silent and inaccessible time.
rejectText: From hand to hand passed browned photos with their backs stained by every finger that had held them in other meals, a mixture of coffee and grease melted into an indefinable color. In the stiff and serious newlyweds, the wedding guests staggered in several rows along a wall, neither his parents nor anyone else could be recognized. It was not oneself either that one saw in the baby of indistinct sex half-naked on a cushion but someone else, a creature belonging to a mute and inaccessible time.
difficult_choice: YES, both translations are close in quality and it was hard to choose between them.
comment:
This paragraph is difficult without larger context. "Mariés" is more likely to mean "newlyweds," in which case "parents" is the best translation for the French "parents." If, however, the photo is talking about a "wedding party," I would think "relatives" is the appropriate translation.
Though T2 omits the detail of the coffee and grease stains and mixes "wedding party" and "parents," I chose it over T1 because of T1's grammatical errors, which to me are much more distracting than some minor omissions or mistranslations: the preposition "in" instead of "at [other meals]" and the switching between third person generic (one) and third person masculine (his).

source: Récit familial et récit social c’est tout un. Les voix des convives délimitaient les espaces de la jeunesse : la campagne et les fermes où, de mémoire perdue, les hommes avaient été commis et les filles servantes, l’usine où tous s’étaient rencontrés, fréquentés et mariés, les petits commerces où avaient accédé les plus ambitieux. Elles dessinaient des histoires sans événements personnels autres que les naissances, les mariages et les deuils, sans voyages en dehors du régiment dans une lointaine ville de garnison, des existences occupées par le travail, sa dureté et son usure, les menaces de la boisson. L’école était un arrière-fond mythique, un bref âge d’or dont l’Instituteur avait été le dieu rude avec sa règle en fer pour taper sur les doigts.
choiceText: Family stories and social stories were one and the same. The voices of the guests outlined the spaces of their youth: the countryside and the farms where, from time immemorial, the men had been hired hands and the girls servants, the factory where they had all met, courted and married, the small businesses to which the most ambitious had aspired. They drew stories with no personal events other than births, marriages and deaths, no travels outside of the regiment to a distant garrison town, lives occupied by work, its hardness and its weariness, the threat of alcohol. School was a mythical background, a brief golden age of which the teacher had been the stern god with his iron ruler to rap on the knuckles.
rejectText: Family story and social story are all one. The voices of the guests delimited the spaces of youth: the countryside and the farms where, from lost memory, the men had been clerks and the girls servants, the factory where all had met, frequented and married, the small shops where the most ambitious had acceded. They drew stories without personal events other than births, marriages and bereavements, without trips outside the regiment to a distant garrison town, of lives filled with work, its hardness and wear and tear, the threats of drink. The school was a mythical background, a brief golden age of which the Teacher had been the rough god with his iron ruler to tap on the fingers.
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment: I chose T2. Once again, the primary issue with T1 is that it is too literal - including ungrammatical articles, messing up set phrases ("are all one" in the first sentence), awkward syntax ("without trips outside the regiment to a distant garrison town), and inappropriate word choice based on context or register ("clerks" on the farm, "bereavements"). T1 also chose cognates that are incorrect: "frequented" for "fréquenté," "acceded" for "accédé," "tap" for "taper."

source: La frénésie qui avait suivi la Libération s’estompait. Alors les gens ne pensaient qu’à sortir et le monde était plein de désirs à satisfaire sur-le-champ. Tout ce qui constituait la première fois depuis la guerre provoquait la ruée, les bananes, les billets de la Loterie nationale, le feu d’artifice. Par quartiers entiers, de la grand-mère soutenue par ses filles au nourrisson en landau, les gens se précipitaient à la fête foraine, à la retraite aux flambeaux, au cirque Bouglione où ils manquaient être piétinés dans la bousculade. Ils se portaient en foule priante et chantante sur la route pour accueillir la statue de Notre-Dame de Boulogne et la reconduire le lendemain sur des kilomètres. Profane ou religieuse, toute occasion leur était bonne d’être au-dehors ensemble, comme s’ils voulaient continuer de vivre collectivement. Le dimanche soir, les cars revenaient de la mer avec de grands jeunes gens en short qui chantaient à tue-tête, grimpés sur le toit à bagages. Les chiens se promenaient en liberté et s’accouplaient au milieu de la rue.
choiceText: The frenzy that had followed liberation was beginning to die down. Now people just wanted to get out and there were a lot of desires that needed to be satisfied right away. Anything that was a first since the war caused a rush, like bananas, lottery tickets, and fireworks. Entire neighborhoods, from grandmothers supported by their daughters to babies in prams, rushed to the fair, the torchlight parade, and Bouglione's circus, where they almost got trampled in the stampede. They went in a praying and singing crowd to the road to welcome the statue of Our Lady of Boulogne and accompany it the next day for miles. Whether it was secular or religious, any occasion was good enough for them to be outside together, as if they wanted to keep living collectively. Sunday night, the buses came back from the sea with tall young people in shorts singing at the top of their lungs, perched on the roof of the luggage rack. Dogs roamed freely and mated in the middle of the street.
rejectText: The frenzy that had followed the Liberation was fading. So people thought only of going out and the world was full of desires to be satisfied on the spot. Everything that constituted the first time since the war caused the rush, the bananas, the National Lottery tickets, the fireworks. Whole quarters, from the grandmother supported by her daughters to the infant in a pram, people rushed to the carnival, to the torchlight procession, to the Bouglione circus where they were almost trampled in the rush. They went in a praying and singing crowd on the road to welcome the statue of Notre-Dame de Boulogne and to drive it back the next day for miles. Secular or religious, any opportunity was good for them to be outside together, as if they wanted to continue to live collectively. On Sunday evening, the coaches returned from the sea with tall young men in shorts, singing at the top of their voices, climbing onto the luggage roof. The dogs roamed free and mated in the middle of the street.
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment:
T2 got two things right that no other translation has: it left "Notre Dame de Boulogne" untranslated, and included "back" in its verb choice for "reconduire." T1 chose "accompany" which omits the "re-" aspect of the verb (aspectual prefix), and therefore completely changes the meaning.
That being said, T2 made literal choices that don't fit: "luggage roof" is a literal translation of the words, but not the term, and is therefore nonsense; all the "the"s in the third sentence are necessary in French but ungrammatical in English; and though it included "back," "drive" is certainly not the right verb for the situation described. Additionally, T2 chose words that are technically correct but an inappropriate register: "quarters" (depending on your definition of "quarter"), "infant in a pram," etc.
T1 isn't a great translation either, but its mistranslations are close and it has no grammatical errors.

source: Les enfants n’écoutaient pas et se dépêchaient de quitter la table dès qu’ils en avaient reçu la permission, profitant de la bienveillance générale des jours de fête pour se livrer aux jeux interdits, sauter sur les lits et faire de la balançoire la tête en bas. Mais ils retenaient tout. À côté du temps fabuleux — dont ils n’ordonneraient pas avant longtemps les épisodes, la Débâcle, l’Exode, l’Occupation, le Débarquement, la Victoire — ils trouvaient terne celui, sans nom, où ils grandissaient. Ils regrettaient de ne pas avoir été nés, ou à peine, quand il fallait partir en cohorte sur les routes et dormir sur la paille comme des bohémiens. De ce temps non vécu ils garderaient le regret tenace. La mémoire des autres leur refilait une nostalgie secrète pour cette époque qu’ils avaient manquée de si peu et l’espérance de la vivre un jour.
choiceText: The children paid no attention and, as soon as they were allowed, they hurried away from the table, taking advantage of the general good-will of the holiday to indulge in forbidden games, jumping on the beds and swinging upside down. But they remembered everything. Beside the fabulous time—the episodes of which they would not be able to arrange for a long time yet—the Debacle, the Exodus, the Occupation, the Landing, the Victory—they found the nameless one in which they were growing up dull. They regretted not having been born, or at least only just, when it was necessary to set out in a cohort on the roads and sleep on straw like gypsies. They would keep a tenacious regret for this time they had missed by so little, and the memory of the others would pass on to them a secret nostalgia for this epoch and the hope of living it one day.
rejectText: The children did not listen and rushed to leave the table as soon as they received permission, taking advantage of the general goodwill of the holidays to indulge in forbidden games, jumping on the beds and swinging their heads. down. But they held everything back. Next to the fabulous time - whose episodes they would not order for a long time, the Debacle, the Exodus, the Occupation, the Landing, the Victory - they found dull the nameless one in which they grew up. They regretted not having been born, or barely, when they had to set off in cohorts on the roads and sleep on the straw like bohemians. Of this unlived time they would keep the tenacious regret. The memories of others gave them a secret nostalgia for this time they had missed so little and the hope of living it one day.
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment:
I chose T1. T2 is too literal with a 1-to-1 translation. The syntax is often awkward (ex: "they found dull the nameless one in which they grew up"), word choice can be unnatural (ex: "as soon as they received permission," "they would not order," etc.), and there will be grammatical errors (ex: regret OF this time vs. regret FOR this time). Oddly, they didn't go literal when it came to "when they had to set off," instead assuming that since "They" was the subject of the sentence, it must carry over -- when in fact it literally says "when it was necessary."
It must be some sort of glitch that created "swinging their heads. down."

source: Ils embrayaient par comparaison sur la guerre d’avant, la Grande, celle de 14, gagnée, elle, dans le sang et la gloire, une guerre d’hommes que les femmes de la table écoutaient avec respect. Ils parlaient du Chemin des Dames et de Verdun, des gazés, des cloches du 11 novembre 1918. Ils nommaient des villages dont pas un enfant parti au front n’était revenu. Ils opposaient les soldats dans la boue des tranchées aux prisonniers de 40, au chaud et à l’abri pendant cinq ans, qui n’avaient même pas reçu de bombes sur la tête. Ils se disputaient l’héroïsme et le malheur.
choiceText: They then compared the present war with the Great War of 1914, won in blood and glory, a war of men which the women at the table listened to with respect. They spoke of the Chemin des Dames and Verdun, of the gassed, of the bells of the 11th of November 1918. They named villages from which not one child who had gone to the front had returned. They contrasted the soldiers in the mud of the trenches with the prisoners of 1940, warm and safe for five years, who had not even had a bomb dropped on their heads. They argued about heroism and misfortune.
rejectText: By comparison, they were gearing up to the war before, the Great, that of 14, won, it, in blood and glory, a war of men that the women at the table listened to with respect. They spoke of the Chemin des Dames and Verdun, of the gassed, of the bells of November 11, 1918. They named villages from which not a child who had gone to the front had returned. They pitted the soldiers in the mud of the trenches against the prisoners of 40, warm and sheltered for five years, who had not even received bombs on the head. They fought over heroism and misfortune.
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment:
T1 added that they were comparing WWI to "the present war" (currently marked as mistranslation) when this phrase is not found in the source, and there is indication later that WWII is already over (prisoners in '40 were held 5 years).
Still, T1 is far superior to T2. The first half of the first sentence in T2 is pretty ridiculous, with a major mistranslation and "the Great, that of 14, won, it, in blood and glory." While T1's "who had not even had a bomb dropped on their heads" comes across inappropriate, it at least sounds more natural compared to "who had not even received bombs on the head." Lastly, I think it's okay to shorten the years as in the source text (T1 expands them to "1914" and "1940"), in English we use an apostrophe, so 14 in the original should be '14 in the translation, 40 should be '40.

source: Mais ils ne parlaient que de ce qu’ils avaient vu, qui pouvait se revivre en mangeant et buvant. Ils n’avaient pas assez de talent ou de conviction pour parler de ce qu’ils savaient mais qu’ils n’avaient pas vu. Donc ni des enfants juifs montant dans des trains pour Auschwitz, ni des morts de faim ramassés au matin dans le ghetto de Varsovie, ni des 10 000 degrés à Hiroshima. D’où cette impression que les cours d’histoire, les documentaires et les films, plus tard, ne dissiperaient pas : ni les fours crématoires ni la bombe atomique ne se situaient dans la même époque que le beurre au marché noir, les alertes et les descentes à la cave.
choiceText: But they only spoke of what they had seen, which could be relived through eating and drinking. They lacked the talent or the conviction to talk about what they knew but had not seen. So there was no mention of Jewish children boarding trains to Auschwitz, of the dead of hunger picked up in the morning in the Warsaw ghetto, or of the 10,000 degrees at Hiroshima. Hence the impression that history classes, documentaries and films later on would not dispel: neither the crematoria nor the atomic bomb belonged to the same era as the black market butter, the air raid sirens and the trips to the cellar.
rejectText: But they spoke only of what they had seen, which could be relived by eating and drinking. They didn't have enough talent or conviction to talk about what they knew but hadn't seen. So neither Jewish children boarding trains for Auschwitz, nor dead of starvation picked up in the morning in the Warsaw ghetto, nor 10,000 degrees in Hiroshima. Hence this impression that later history lessons, documentaries and films would not dissipate: neither the crematory ovens nor the atomic bomb were situated in the same era as butter on the black market, scares and the descents to the cellar.
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment:
Both translations once again mistranslate "en" as "through" or "by," when it should be "while" -- these stories can be relived WHILE eating and drinking.
T1 is clearly superior simply if you look at the annotations. I highlighted "neither" as a grammatical error because I think unless you adapt the structure of the sentence as T1 did, "ni" should in this case be translated as "no," but I'm not sure if this is an actual error, or if it's simply that it's awkward.

source: Sous l’immuabilité, les affiches du cirque de l’année dernière avec la photo de Roger Lanzac, les images de première communion distribuées aux camarades, le Club des Chansonniers sur Radio Luxembourg, les jours se remplissaient de désirs nouveaux. Le dimanche après-midi, on s’agglutinait à la vitrine du magasin d’électricité générale devant la télévision. Des cafés investissaient dans l’achat d’un poste pour attirer la clientèle. Au flanc des collines serpentaient des pistes de motocross et l’on regardait monter et descendre les engins assourdissants la journée entière. L’impatience grandissante du commerce avec ses nouveaux mots d’ordre, « initiative », « dynamisme », secouait le train-train des villes. Entre la fête foraine et la kermesse, la Quinzaine commerciale s’installait comme rite de printemps. Dans les rues du centre, les haut-parleurs beuglaient des incitations à acheter, entrecoupées de chansons d’Annie Cordy et d’Eddie Constantine, pour gagner la Simca ou la salle à manger. Sur le podium, place de la Mairie, un animateur local faisait rire avec les blagues de Roger Nicolas et de Jean Richard, rameutait des candidats pour le Crochet ou Quitte ou double, comme à la radio. Assise dans un coin du podium trônait sous sa couronne la Reine du Commerce. La marchandise avançait sous les couleurs de la fête. Les gens disaient « ça change » ou « il ne faut pas s’encroûter, on s’abrutit à rester chez soi ».
choiceText: Beneath the immutability, last year's circus posters with the photo of Roger Lanzac, the pictures of first communion distributed to comrades, the Chansonniers Club on Radio Luxembourg, the days were filled with new desires. On Sunday afternoons, we gathered in the window of the general electricity store in front of the television. Cafes invested in the purchase of a station to attract customers. Along the hillsides snaked motocross tracks and we watched the deafening machines go up and down the whole day. The growing impatience of commerce with its new watchwords, “initiative”, “dynamism”, shook the routine of the cities. Between the carnival and the fair, the Commercial Fortnight was established as a spring rite. In the streets of the center, the loudspeakers bellowed incitements to buy, interspersed with songs of Annie Cordy and Eddie Constantine, to win the Simca or the dining room. On the podium, Place de la Mairie, a local host made laughs with the jokes of Roger Nicolas and Jean Richard, rounded up candidates for Crochet or Quitte ou double, as on the radio. Seated in a corner of the podium was enthroned under her crown the Queen of Commerce. The merchandise moved forward under the colors of the party. People said "it's a change" or "we mustn't get stuck, we're stupid to stay at home".
rejectText: Under the immutability, the posters of the circus of last year with the photo of Roger Lanzac, the first communion images distributed to the comrades, the Club of Songwriters on Radio Luxembourg, the days were filled with new desires. On Sunday afternoons, people crowded around the window of the general electrical store in front of the television. Cafes invested in the purchase of a set to attract customers. On the slopes of the hills, motocross tracks snaked and one watched the deafening machines go up and down all day. The growing impatience of commerce with its new slogans, "initiative", "dynamism", shook the daily routine of the cities. Between the fair and the fair, the Commercial Fortnight settled as a rite of spring. In the streets of the center, the loudspeakers roared with invitations to buy, interspersed with songs by Annie Cordy and Eddie Constantine, to win the Simca or the dining room. On the podium, Place de la Mairie, a local animator made people laugh with the jokes of Roger Nicolas and Jean Richard, rounded up candidates for the Crochet or Quitte or double, as on the radio. Seated in a corner of the podium, the Queen of Commerce reigned under her crown. The merchandise advanced under the colors of the party. People said "it changes" or "you must not get stuck, you get dull staying at home".
difficult_choice: YES, both translations are close in quality and it was hard to choose between them.
comment:
Both translations made similar errors in translation choices and punctuation (in AE commas go inside quotation marks), and each one made a glaring error that made it hard to choose: T1 had the phrase "Between the fair and the fair" which is nonsense, and in T2 the host "made laughs." 
T2 also chose to use the pronoun "we" instead of the generic "one," which could be wrong depending on larger context that we don't have; without context, it should be left as "one" because there's no indication that the narrator was there, and using the pronoun "on" as first person plural is much more common in spoken French than in written French.
I chose T2 because 
- even if "fair" isn't totally right for "kermesse," at least it's a different word from their choice for "fête foraine" ("Between the carnival and the fair")
- "incitements" vs "invitations" is truer to the original meaning and "invitations" changes the overall mood
- "Chansonniers Club" is closer than "Club of Songwriters" (should be left untranslated as it was a famous broadcast)
- more mistranslations in T1 than in T2

source: Les garçons étaient fiers de partir au régiment et on les trouvait beaux en soldats. Le soir du conseil de révision, ils faisaient la tournée des cafés pour célébrer la gloire d’être reconnus comme de vrais hommes. Avant le régiment, ils étaient encore des gamins et ne valaient rien sur le marché du travail et du mariage. Après, ils pourraient avoir une femme et des enfants. L’uniforme qu’ils promenaient dans le quartier lors des permissions les enveloppait de beauté patriotique et de sacrifice virtuel. L’ombre des combattants vainqueurs, des GI, flottait autour d’eux. Le drap rêche de la vareuse, effleurée quand on se hissait sur la pointe des pieds pour les embrasser, matérialisait la coupure absolue entre l’univers des hommes et celui des femmes. À les voir on éprouvait un sentiment d’héroïsme.
choiceText: The boys were proud to go to the regiment and they were thought to be handsome as soldiers. On the night of the review board, they made the rounds of cafes to celebrate the glory of being recognized as real men. Before the regiment, they were still kids and were worthless on the job and marriage market. Afterwards, they could have a wife and children. The uniform they paraded around the neighborhood on leave enveloped them in patriotic beauty and virtual sacrifice. The shadow of the victorious fighters, of the GIs, floated around them. The rough sheet of the smock, brushed when you stood on tiptoe to kiss them, materialized the absolute cut between the world of men and that of women. Seeing them one felt a sense of heroism.
rejectText: The boys were proud to be leaving for the regiment and they looked handsome in their uniforms. On the night of their conscription review they went around the bars to celebrate the glory of being recognized as real men. Before the regiment they had been just kids and worth nothing in the job or marriage market. Afterwards they could have a wife and children. The uniform they wore around the neighborhood on leave was wrapped in patriotic beauty and virtual sacrifice. The shadow of victorious fighters, GIs, floated around them. The rough cloth of the tunic, brushed when you stood on tiptoe to kiss them, materialized the absolute break between the world of men and that of women. Seeing them gave one a feeling of heroism.
difficult_choice: YES, both translations are close in quality and it was hard to choose between them.
comment: T1 had more mistakes, but T2's mistake was worse in my opinion: "enveloppait" is active, T2 makes it passive. The uniforms wrap the soldiers up, the uniform itself is not wrapped.

source: Une autre photo, signée du même photographe — mais le papier du livret est plus ordinaire et le liseré d’or a disparu —, sans doute vouée à la même distribution familiale, montre une petite fille d’environ quatre ans, sérieuse, presque triste malgré une bonne bouille rebondie sous des cheveux courts, séparés par une raie au milieu et tirés en arrière par des barrettes auxquelles sont attachés des rubans, comme des papillons. La main gauche repose sur la même table sculptée, entièrement visible, de style Louis XVI. Elle apparaît boudinée dans son corsage, sa jupe à bretelles remonte par-devant à cause d’un ventre proéminent, peut-être signe de rachitisme (1944, environ).
choiceText: Another photograph, signed by the same photographer - but the paper of the booklet is more ordinary and the gilt edging has disappeared - no doubt destined for the same family distribution, shows a little girl of about four years old, serious, almost sad despite a good round face under short hair, parted in the middle and pulled back with barrettes to which ribbons are attached, like butterflies. Her left hand rests on the same carved table, fully visible, in Louis XVI style. She appears plump in her blouse, her pinafore rising in front due to a prominent stomach, perhaps a sign of rickets (1944, approximately).
rejectText: Another photo, signed by the same photographer - but the paper of the booklet is more ordinary and the gold border has disappeared -, undoubtedly dedicated to the same family distribution, shows a little girl of about four years old, serious, almost sad despite a nice plump face under short hair, separated by a parting in the middle and pulled back by bars to which are attached ribbons, like butterflies. The left hand rests on the same sculpted table, entirely visible, in the Louis XVI style. She appears pudgy in her bodice, her suspender skirt goes up in front because of a protruding belly, perhaps a sign of rickets (1944, circa).
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment: As you can see, T1 had considerably more mistranslations, though it did get "suspender skirt" right and "nice plump face" is much better than "good round face." T1 also made the punctuation error of "--," which is common in French but not used in English. T1 gives a literal translation but doesn't seem to account for context; for one example, "sculpté" can mean either "sculpted" or "carved," though the two have very distinct meanings in English, and a Louis XVI table is carved from wood, not sculpted.

source: Deux autres petites photos à bords dentelés, datant vraisemblablement de la même année, montrent la même enfant, mais plus menue, dans une robe à volants et manches ballon. Sur la première, elle se blottit de façon espiègle contre une femme au corps massif, d’un seul tenant dans une robe à larges rayures, les cheveux relevés en gros rouleaux. Sur l’autre, elle lève le poing gauche, le droit est retenu par la main d’un homme, grand, en veste claire et pantalon à pinces, à la posture nonchalante. Les deux photos ont été prises le même jour devant un muret surmonté d’une bordure de fleurs, dans une cour pavée. Au-dessus des têtes passe une corde à linge sur laquelle une épingle est restée accrochée.
choiceText: Two other small, scalloped-edged photographs, probably taken in the same year, show the same child, now more slender, in a dress with flounces and balloon sleeves. In the first she is mischievously snuggling up to a woman with a solid body, wearing a dress with wide stripes, her hair in big curls. In the second she is raising her left fist, her right being held by a tall man in a light jacket and pinstriped trousers, with a nonchalant air. The two photographs were taken on the same day in front of a wall with a flower border, in a paved courtyard. Above their heads a clothesline passes, with a pin still hooked on it.
rejectText: Two other small jagged-edged photos, presumably from the same year, show the same child, but smaller, in a ruffled dress with balloon sleeves. In the first, she playfully snuggles up to a massively bodied, one-piece woman in a wide-striped dress, her hair up in big rolls. On the other, she raises her left fist, the right is held by the hand of a man, tall, in a light jacket and pleated trousers, with a nonchalant posture. The two photos were taken the same day in front of a low wall surmounted by a border of flowers, in a paved courtyard. Above the heads passes a clothesline on which a pin has remained hung.
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment:
**I can't believe I missed this in every other batch, but "rouleaux" has been mistranslated every time; the woman's hair is up in curlers or rollers.
I've chosen T2 because T1 is too literal, too 1-to-1, and therefore has some issues with grammar (prepositions in particular are hardly ever a 1-to-1 translation). This also causes awkward phrasing like "the right is held by the hand of a man, tall...", "pin has remained hung."
T1 misses the minor detail of the wall only being topped with flowers, but T2's awkward choice of "surmounted" is probably as bad as the omission.

source: »Was soll es denn sonst gewesen sein«, sagte Selma, und dass man ein Okapi ja nur schwerlich mit einem anderen Tier verwechseln könne. »Doch«, sagte ich, es könne ja auch ein verwachsenes Rind gewesen sein, eine falsch zusammengesetzte Giraffe, eine Laune der Natur, und die Streifen und das Rostrote, das könne man doch alles nicht so genau erkennen in der Nacht, da sei schließlich alles sehr verschwommen. »Das ist doch Quatsch«, sagte Selma und rieb sich die Stirn, »das ist doch leider Quatsch, Luise.« Sie legte eine Scheibe Käse auf das Brot, klappte es zusammen und legte es in meine Butterbrotdose. »Weißt du, wann genau du das geträumt hast?« »Gegen drei Uhr«, sagte Selma. Sie war hochgeschreckt, nachdem das Bild vom Okapi sich zurückgezogen hatte, aufrecht im Bett sitzend war sie aufgewacht und hatte auf ihr Nachthemd gestarrt, in dem sie eben noch im Traum auf der Uhlheck gestanden hatte, und dann auf den Wecker. Drei Uhr. »Wir sollten das wahrscheinlich nicht so ernst nehmen«, sagte Selma, aber sie sagte es wie ein Fernsehkommissar, der ein anonymes Schreiben nicht so ernst nimmt.
choiceText: "What else could it have been," Selma said, adding that it would be hard to confuse an okapi with any other animal. "But," I said, "it could also have been a deformed cow, a wrongly assembled giraffe, a whim of nature, and the stripes and the rust-red color, you couldn't really make out all that in the night, everything was so blurry." "That's nonsense," Selma said, rubbing her forehead. "Unfortunately, it's nonsense, Luise." She put a slice of cheese on the bread, folded it in half, and put it in my sandwich box. "Do you know exactly when you dreamed this?" "Around three o'clock," Selma said. She had woken up with a start after the image of the okapi had faded away, sitting upright in bed, staring at her nightgown in which she had just been standing on the Uhlheck in her dream, and then at the alarm clock. Three o'clock. "We probably shouldn't take this too seriously," Selma said, but she said it like a TV detective who doesn't take an anonymous letter too seriously.
rejectText: "What else could it have been," said Selma, and that one could hardly confuse an okapi with any other animal. "Yes," I said, it could also have been an overgrown cow, a giraffe that was put together incorrectly, a whim of nature, and the stripes and the rust-red color, you can't really see all that exactly at night, that's where it is after all everything very blurry. "That's nonsense," said Selma, rubbing her forehead, "unfortunately that's nonsense, Luise." She put a slice of cheese on the bread, folded it up and put it in my lunch box. "Do you know when exactly you dreamed that?" "Around three o'clock," said Selma. She had been startled after the image of the okapi had receded, she had woken up sitting up in bed and stared at her nightgown, in which she had just dreamed of standing on the Uhlheck, and then at the alarm clock. Three o'clock. "We probably shouldn't take this so seriously," Selma said, but she said it like a TV detective who doesn't take an anonymous letter too seriously.
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment: Here again, the translation is very word by word (T2). This reflects in the flow (not great) and the style (coarse).

source: »Klappe halten«, sagte der Optiker noch einmal lauter und ging schneller, »Selma findet nur sehr selten etwas bedrohlich oder unansehnlich.« Damit hatte er völlig recht, und damit hatte er leider mehr gesagt, als er den Stimmen eigentlich hätte antworten sollen. Aber die Liebe fände sie womöglich ausgerechnet doch unansehnlich, zischelten die Stimmen, es habe ja einen Grund, sagten sie, dass die Wahrheit so lange verborgen wurde. »Feigheit war das«, sagte der Optiker und schob die Ledertasche auf die andere Hüfte, weil das Rempeln der Tasche und das Rempeln der Stimmen langsam begannen wehzutun. »Besonnenheit war das«, sagten die Stimmen, »Angst ist ja manchmal doch ein guter Ratgeber«, sagten sie und summten die Titelmelodie der Vorabendserie. Der Optiker wurde jetzt langsamer. Der Weg zu Selmas Haus, der eigentlich zehn Minuten dauerte, kam ihm plötzlich vor wie eine Tagesreise, eine Tagesreise mit sehr, sehr viel Gepäck.
choiceText: "Shut up," the optician said louder again and walked faster, "Selma rarely finds anything threatening or unsightly." He was absolutely right about that, and unfortunately he said more than he should have answered the voices. But they might find love unsightly after all, the voices hissed, there was a reason, they said, that the truth had been hidden for so long. "That was cowardice," said the optician, shifting the leather bag to his other hip because the bumping of the bag and the bumping of the voices were starting to hurt. "That was prudence," said the voices, "Fear is sometimes a good guide, after all," they said and hummed the title tune of the previous evening's series. The optometrist was now slowing down. The way to Selma's house, which actually took ten minutes, suddenly felt like a day's journey, a day's journey with a lot of luggage.
rejectText: "Be quiet," the optician said again, louder this time, and he walked faster. "Selma rarely finds anything threatening or unsightly." He was completely right, and unfortunately he had said more than he should have answered to the voices. But maybe love would find her unsightly, the voices hissed. There must be a reason, they said, why the truth had been hidden for so long. "That was cowardice," the optician said, shifting the leather bag to his other hip, because the jostling of the bag and the jostling of the voices was beginning to hurt. "That was prudence," the voices said. "Fear can sometimes be a good advisor," they said, and they hummed the theme song of the evening show. The optician was now walking slower. The path to Selma's house, which usually took ten minutes, suddenly seemed to him like a day's journey, a day's journey with a lot, a lot of baggage.
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment:
I prefer T1 over T2. I think this might be the first translation that didn't change the subject in the sentence "Aber die Liebe fände sie womöglich ausgerechnet doch unansehnlich," which is usually wrongly translated as "but maybe love would find her unsightly", and should be correctly translated as "But she might find love unsightly,". True, T1 still wrongly translated "sie" as "they", while in this context it should be translated as "she", but this is still a major improvement. 
This is also the first translation that correctly chose the register and translated "Klappe halten" as "shut up" rather than the mild and overly polite "be quiet".
"the bumping of the bag and the bumping of the voices were starting to hurt." isn't technically correct collocationwise, but I'd be willing to accept the repeated bumping in this sentence as a stylistic device that gives a nice ring to it.

One thing I didn't like in T1 was the translation of "Ratgeber" as "guide," even though it's clearly an advisor.

source: Das stimmte. Der Hund war schneematschfarben, er war verwaschen grau und zottelig wie ein ausschließlicher Irischer Wolfhund ohne etwas anderes drin. Sein Körper war noch klein, aber seine Pfoten waren groß wie Bärentatzen, und wir wussten alle, was das bedeutete. Selma stand immer noch erhoben vor der Küchenbank. Sie schaute lange auf den Hund. Dann sah sie meinen Vater an, als sei er ein Geschenkideengeschäft.
choiceText: That was true. The dog was slush-colored, it was a faded gray and shaggy like an all-Irish Wolfhound with nothing else in it. His body was small, but his paws were as big as bear paws, and we all knew what that meant. Selma was still standing in front of the kitchen bench. She looked at the dog for a long time. Then she looked at my father like he was a gift shop.
rejectText: That was true. The dog was snow-muddy-colored, he was washed-out grey and shaggy like an exclusive Irish Wolfhound without anything else mixed in. His body was still small, but his paws were as big as bear's claws, and we all knew what that meant. Selma was still standing tall in front of the kitchen bench. She looked at the dog for a long time. Then she looked at my father as if he was a gift shop.
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment: Both translations are OK, but T1 used a more concise "slush-colored" compared to "snow-muddy-colored", which is more literal, but also more awkward. It also correctly translated "Bärentatzen" as "bear paws", unlike T2 which used "bear claws" instead.

source: Bauer Häubel war der festen Überzeugung, dass der Tod höflich sein würde, so wie Bauer Häubel selbst es sein Leben lang gewesen war. Er war sicher, dass der Tod ihm das Leben nicht entreißen, sondern behutsam aus der Hand nehmen würde. Er stellte sich vor, wie der Tod vorsichtig anklopfte, die Tür nur einen Spalt öffnete und »Darf ich?« fragte, was Bauer Häubel natürlich bejahen würde. »Selbstverständlich«, würde Bauer Häubel sagen, »treten Sie doch ein«, und der Tod würde eintreten. Er würde sich an Bauer Häubels Bett stellen und fragen: »Passt es Ihnen jetzt? Ich kann sonst auch zu einem späteren Zeitpunkt vorbeikommen.« Bauer Häubel würde sich aufrichten und »Nein, nein, es passt mir gerade sehr gut« sagen, »lassen Sie es uns besser nicht noch einmal verschieben, wer weiß, wann Sie es wieder einrichten können«, und der Tod würde sich auf den schon bereitgestellten Stuhl am Kopfende setzen. Er würde sich im Vorhinein für die Kälte seiner Hände entschuldigen, die, das wusste Bauer Häubel, ihm überhaupt nichts ausmachen würde, und dann eine Hand auf Bauer Häubels Augen legen.
choiceText: Farmer Häubel firmly believed that death would be polite, just as Farmer Häubel himself had been all his life. He was sure that death would not snatch his life away, but would take it gently from his hands. He imagined death knocking cautiously, opening the door just a crack and asking "May I?", which Farmer Häubel would of course answer in the affirmative. "Of course," Farmer Häubel would say, "do come in," and death would follow. He would stand by Bauer Häubel's bed and ask: "Are you okay now? Otherwise I can come by at a later time." Farmer Häubel would sit up and say, "No, no, it suits me just fine right now," "let's not postpone it again, who knows when you'll set it up again can," and Death would sit in the chair already prepared at the head end. He would apologize in advance for the coldness of his hands, which Farmer Häubel knew he wouldn't mind at all, and then put a hand over Farmer Häubel's eyes.
rejectText: Bauer Häubel was firmly convinced that death would be polite, just as he himself had been his whole life. He was sure that death would not snatch his life away, but take it gently from his hand. He imagined death knocking carefully, opening the door only a crack and asking, "May I?" which Bauer Häubel would naturally answer in the affirmative. "Of course," Bauer Häubel would say, "please come in," and death would enter. He would stand by Bauer Häubel's bed and ask, "Is this a good time for you? I can come back at a later time." Bauer Häubel would sit up and say, "No, no, this is a very good time. Let's not put it off again, who knows when you can arrange it again," and death would sit in the chair prepared at the head of the bed. He would apologize in advance for the coldness of his hands, which Bauer Häubel knew would not bother him at all, and then place a hand on Bauer Häubel's eyes.
difficult_choice: YES, both translations are close in quality and it was hard to choose between them.
comment: T2 is better, but marginally. Aside from the fact that T2 translated "Bauer" and T1 didn't, the two translations are of very similar quality.

source: Die Leute im Dorf waren beunruhigt, man sah es ihnen an, auch wenn sie größtenteils versuchten, sich nichts anmerken zu lassen. Heute Morgen, wenige Stunden nach Selmas Traum, bewegten sich die Leute im Dorf, als habe sich auf allen Wegen Blitzeis gebildet, nicht nur draußen, sondern auch in den Häusern, Blitzeis in den Küchen und Wohnzimmern. Sie bewegten sich, als seien ihnen die eigenen Körper ganz fremd, als seien all ihre Gelenke entzündet und auch die Gegenstände, mit denen sie hantierten, hochentzündlich. Den ganzen Tag lang beargwöhnten sie ihr Leben und, soweit möglich, das aller anderen. Immer wieder schauten sie hinter sich, um zu überprüfen, ob da jemand angesprungen käme mit Mordlust, jemand, der den Verstand verloren und deshalb nichts Nennenswertes mehr zu verlieren hatte, und sie schauten rasch wieder nach vorne, weil jemand ohne Verstand schließlich auch frontal angreifen konnte. Sie schauten nach oben, um herabfallende Dachziegel, Äste oder schwere Lampenschirme auszuschließen. Sie mieden alle Tiere, weil es aus denen, glaubten sie, schneller herausbrechen konnte als aus Menschen. Sie machten einen Bogen um die gutartigen Kühe, die heute womöglich austreten würden, sie mieden die Hunde, auch die ganz alten, die kaum noch stehen konnten, ihnen aber heute vielleicht trotzdem an die Gurgel gehen würden. An solchen Tagen war alles möglich, da konnten einem auch vergreiste Dackel die Kehle durchbeißen, viel abwegiger als ein Okapi war das schließlich nicht.
choiceText: The people in the village were worried, you could see it in them, even if they mostly tried not to show it. This morning, a few hours after Selma's dream, the people in the village were moving as if black ice had formed on all paths, not only outside but also in the houses, black ice in the kitchens and living rooms. They moved as if their own bodies were completely foreign to them, as if all their joints were inflamed and the objects they were handling were also highly flammable. All day long they suspected their lives and, if possible, everyone else's. They kept looking behind them to see if there was someone lunging at them with a lust for murder, someone who had lost their minds and therefore had nothing significant to lose, and they quickly looked ahead again because someone without their minds would end up attacking head-on could. They looked up to rule out falling tiles, branches, or heavy lampshades. They avoided all animals because they believed it could break out of them faster than out of people. They avoided the good-natured cows that might escape today, they avoided the dogs, even the very old ones that could barely stand but might still have a go at their throats today. Anything was possible on days like this, even an aged dachshund could bite your throat, after all it wasn't much more outlandish than an okapi.
rejectText: The people in the village were uneasy; it was visible, even though most of them tried to show nothing. This morning, only a few hours after Selma's dream, the people in the village moved as if lightning had frozen on all paths, not only outside but also in the houses, lightning in the kitchens and living rooms. They moved as if their own bodies were completely foreign to them, as if all their joints were inflamed and even the objects they handled were highly flammable. All day long they suspected their own lives and, as far as possible, that of others. Again and again they looked back to check if someone would jump at them with murderous intent, someone who had lost their mind and therefore had nothing more to lose, and they quickly looked forward again because someone without a mind could also attack head-on. They looked up to exclude falling roof tiles, branches or heavy lampshades. They avoided all animals, because they believed that something could break out of them faster than out of humans. They made a detour around the gentle cows that might pee today, they avoided the dogs, even the very old ones that could hardly stand anymore, but who might still go for their throats today. On such days, anything was possible, it was not much more absurd than an okapi for an old dachshund to bite through one's throat.
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment: T2 is much better, stylewise and flowwise. Also, this is the only translation in all of the German batches that got the translation of "Blitzeis" right, translated as "black ice".

source: Bis auf Selmas Schwägerin Elsbeth waren die Leute im Dorf meistens nicht abergläubisch. Sie machten unbekümmert all das, was man bei Aberglauben nicht machen darf: Sie saßen gelassen unter Wanduhren, obwohl man bei Aberglauben daran sterben kann, sie schliefen mit dem Kopf zur Tür hin, obwohl das bei Aberglauben bedeutet, dass man durch genau die Tür bald mit den Füßen zuerst hinausgetragen wird. Sie hängten zwischen Weihnachten und Neujahr Wäsche auf, was, wie Elsbeth warnte, bei Aberglauben einem Suizid oder einer Beihilfe zum Mord gleichkommt. Sie erschraken nicht, wenn nachts das Käuzchen rief, wenn ein Pferd im Stall stark schwitzte, wenn ein Hund nachts jaulte, mit gesenktem Kopf.
choiceText: Apart from Selma's sister-in-law Elsbeth, most people in the village were not superstitious. They did all the things that superstition forbids: they sat calmly under wall clocks, even though superstition says that it can kill you; they slept with their heads towards the door, even though superstition says that it means you will be carried out of the door feet first; they hung out laundry between Christmas and New Year, which, as Elsbeth warned, was akin to suicide or aiding and abetting murder according to superstition. They were not scared when the screech owl called at night, when a horse sweated heavily in the stable, or when a dog howled with its head down at night.
rejectText: Except for Selma's sister-in-law Elsbeth, most of the people in the village were not superstitious. They blithely did everything that superstitions shouldn't do: they sat serenely under wall clocks, although superstitions can kill you, they slept with their heads towards the door, although superstitions mean you'll be walking through that very door soon being carried out feet first. They hung out laundry between Christmas and New Year's, which Elsbeth warned is, to superstition, tantamount to suicide or an accessory to murder. They weren't startled when the owl cried at night, when a horse sweated profusely in the stable, when a dog howled at night with its head down.
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment: Compared to T1, T2 is very literal and has mistranslations clearly stemming from sticking too closely to the German version. It seems that in T2 the system omitted the preposition "bei", which resulted in "superstition can kill you" instead of "according to the superstition it can kill you", and "superstitions mean" instead of "according to the superstition it means"

source: Die Zugfahrt dauerte fünfzehn Minuten, einen Zwischenhalt gab es nicht. Seit unserer ersten Zugfahrt spielten wir immer dasselbe: Wir stellten uns mit dem Rücken zu den Fenstern an die gegenüberliegenden Zugtüren, Martin machte die Augen zu, ich sah aus dem Fenster der Zugtür, die Martin im Rücken hatte. In der ersten Klasse hatte ich Martin aufgezählt, was ich während der Fahrt sah, und Martin versuchte, alles auswendig zu lernen. Das gelang sehr gut, sodass ich im zweiten Schuljahr nichts mehr aufzählte und Martin, mit dem Rücken zum Fenster und geschlossenen Augen, fast alles aufsagen konnte, was ich durch das beschlagene Zugfenster gerade sah: »Drahtfabrik«, sagte er, genau in dem Moment, als wir an der Drahtfabrik vorbeifuhren. »Jetzt Feld. Weide. Das Gehöft vom verrückten Hassel. Wiese. Wald. Wald. Hochsitz eins. Feld. Wald. Wiese. Weide, Weide. Reifenfabrik. Dorf. Weide. Feld. Hochsitz zwei. Waldstück. Hof. Feld. Wald. Hochsitz drei. Dorf.«
choiceText: The train ride lasted fifteen minutes, with no stops in between. Since our first train ride, we had always played the same game: we stood with our backs to the windows, facing the opposite train doors, Martin closed his eyes, and I looked out of the window of the door that Martin had behind him. In first class, I had listed off to Martin what I saw during the ride, and Martin tried to memorize it all. That worked very well, so that in the second year of school I no longer listed anything and Martin, with his back to the window and his eyes closed, could almost recite everything I saw through the fogged-up train window: "Wire factory," he said, just as we passed the wire factory. "Now a field. Meadow. Hassel's crazy farm. Meadow. Forest. Forest. Hunting stand one. Field. Forest. Meadow. Meadow. Tire factory. Village. Meadow. Field. Hunting stand two. Wooded area. Farm. Field. Forest. Hunting stand three. Village."
rejectText: The train ride lasted fifteen minutes, with no intermediate stops. Ever since our first train journey, we've always played the same thing: we stood with our backs to the windows at the opposite train doors, Martin closed his eyes, I looked out of the window of the train door that had Martin behind me. In first grade, I told Martin what I saw on the drive, and Martin tried to memorize it all. That worked so well that in the second year of school I didn't list anything anymore and Martin, with his back to the window and closed eyes, was able to recite almost everything I was seeing through the fogged-up train window: "Wire factory," he said, at exactly that moment , as we drove past the wire factory. 'Now field. Pasture. Mad Hassel's homestead. Meadow. Forest. Forest. perch one. Field. Forest. Meadow. pasture, pasture. tire factory. Village. Pasture. Field. perch two. piece of forest. Court. Field. Forest. perch three. Village."
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment: First and foremost, style. T1 is word by word to the point it translates Fahrt as "drive" instead of "ride" even though it refers to the trains. T2 has better word choice. It has one mistranslation, "Hassel's crazy farm," that should be "the farm of crazy Hassel", but T1 isn't free of mistranslations either.

source: »Was ist denn?«, fragte ich. »Nichts«, flötete Selma, öffnete den Kühlschrank, holte ein Paket Schnittkäse und eine Leberwurst heraus und schwenkte beides durch die Luft. »Was darf’s denn heute aufs Schulbrot sein?«, flötete sie. »Mäuselchen«, flötete sie noch hinterher, und Flöten und Mäuselchen waren nun wirklich alarmierend. »Käse, bitte«, sagte ich, »was hast du denn?« »Nichts«, flötete Selma, »hab ich doch gesagt.« Sie strich Butter auf eine Scheibe Brot, und weil sie immer noch herumschlackerte, schubste sie dabei den Käse mit dem Handgelenk von der Anrichte. Selma hielt jetzt still und schaute hinab auf die Käsepackung, als sei sie etwas Kostbares, das in tausend Teile zersprungen war.
choiceText: "What is it?" I asked. "Nothing," Selma trilled, opening the refrigerator and taking out a package of sliced cheese and a liver sausage, which she waved around in the air. "What would you like on your school sandwich today?" she trilled again. "Mäuselchen," she trilled once more, and the trilling and Mäuselchen were really alarming. "Cheese, please," I said. "What's wrong with you?" "Nothing," Selma trilled. "I already said that." She spread butter on a slice of bread, and as she was still floundering, she nudged the cheese off the counter with her wrist. Selma now stood still and looked down at the cheese package as if it were something precious that had broken into a thousand pieces.
rejectText: "What is it?" I asked. "Nothing," Selma chirped, opening the fridge, taking out a package of sliced cheese and a liver sausage and waving both through the air. “What would you like for school lunch today?” she whistled. "Little Mouse," she whistled afterwards, and flutes and little mice were now really alarming. "Cheese, please," I said, "what do you have?" "Nothing," Selma chirped, "I told you so." She spread butter on a slice of bread and because she was still flapping around, she nudged the cheese off the sideboard with her wrist. Selma stopped now and looked down at the pack of cheese as if it were something precious that had shattered into a thousand pieces.
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment:
Although T1 has one word untranslated twice, it's not a major problem.  I presume it treated "Mäuselchen" as a proper name, which is not far from true -- it's a way in which Selma is referring to the narrator and it could be translated as "Mousie" or "My little mouse" (the German word is like a double diminutive of the word "mouse").
On the other hand, the mistranslation in the middle in T2 doesn't make much sense. Also T1 uses more fitting words in some places, like "counter" instead of "sideboard."

source: Wenn ich unten bei Selma schlief, erzählte sie mir am Bettrand Geschichten mit guten Enden. Als ich kleiner war, hatte ich nach den Geschichten immer ihr Handgelenk umfasst, meinen Daumen auf ihren Puls gelegt und mir vorgestellt, dass die ganze Welt alles im Rhythmus von Selmas Herzschlag tat. Ich stellte mir vor, wie der Optiker Linsen schliff, Martin ein Gewicht stemmte, Elsbeth ihre Hecke schnitt, wie der Einzelhändler Safttüten einräumte, meine Mutter Tannenzweige aufeinanderschichtete, mein Vater Rezepte stempelte, und alle taten das genau in Selmas Herzrhythmus. Darüber war ich immer verlässlich eingeschlafen, aber jetzt, mit zehn Jahren, fand Selma, sei ich zu alt dafür.
choiceText: When I slept downstairs with Selma, she would tell me bedtime stories with happy endings. When I was younger, I would always hold her wrist, place my thumb on her pulse and imagine that the entire world did everything in the rhythm of Selma's heartbeat. I imagined the optician grinding lenses, Martin lifting weights, Elsbeth trimming her hedge, the grocer stocking juice bags, my mother stacking pine branches, my father stamping prescriptions, and all of them doing it exactly in Selma's heart rhythm. That always reliably put me to sleep, but now, at ten years old, Selma thought I was too old for it.
rejectText: When I slept downstairs with Selma, she would tell me stories with happy endings on the edge of the bed. When I was younger, after the stories, I used to hold her wrist, put my thumb on her pulse, and imagine the whole world doing everything to Selma's heartbeat. I imagined the optometrist grinding lenses, Martin lifting a weight, Elsbeth trimming her hedge, the retailer stocking juice bags, my mother stacking fir branches, my father stamping prescriptions, all doing it right in time with Selma's heartbeat. I had always reliably fallen asleep over it, but now, at the age of ten, Selma thought I was too old for that.
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment: T1 feels way more natural. T2 adds "on the edge of the bed" in the first sentence, which is just a literal translation of "Bettrand", where the intended meaning was to translate "Bettrand Geschichten" as "bedtime stories". Although "lifting a weight" (T2) is technically not an error, it's unnatural especially compared to "lifting weights" (T1).

source: Selma hatte in ihrem Leben dreimal von einem Okapi geträumt, und jedes Mal war danach jemand gestorben, deshalb waren wir überzeugt, dass der Traum von einem Okapi und der Tod unbedingt miteinander verbunden waren. Unser Verstand funktioniert so. Er kann innerhalb kürzester Zeit dafür sorgen, dass die einander abwegigsten Dinge fest zusammengehören. Kaffeekannen und Schnürsenkel beispielsweise, oder Pfandflaschen und Tannenbäume.
choiceText: Selma had dreamed of an okapi three times in her life, and each time someone had died afterwards, so we were convinced that the dream of an okapi and death were inextricably linked. That's how our minds work. In the blink of an eye, they can make the most disparate things belong together. Coffee pots and shoelaces, for example, or deposit bottles and fir trees.
rejectText: Selma had dreamed of an okapi three times in her life, and each time someone died, so we were convinced that the dream of an okapi and death were intrinsically linked. Our mind works like this. Within a very short time, he can ensure that the most absurd things belong together. Coffee pots and shoelaces, for example, or returnable bottles and Christmas trees.
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment: Better style and flow. T2 is rather a word by word translation. No problems such as "mind" being male as in T2. Plus, I have a personal preference for the translation of Tannenbaum as "fir tree" (T1) rather than "Christmas tree" (T2).

source: Alles zu vergessen, ist gewiss schlimm. Noch schlimmer ist, nichts zu vergessen, wird doch jedes Wissen erst durch Vergessen erzeugt. Wenn alles unterschiedslos gespeichert ist, wie auf den elektrische Energie verbrauchenden Datenspeichern, verliert es seine Bedeutung und wird zu einer ungeordneten Ansammlung unbrauchbarer Information.
choiceText: すべてを忘れることは確かに悪いことです。もっと悪いことは、何も忘れないことです。なぜなら、すべての知識は忘れることによって生み出されるからです。電気エネルギーを消費するデータ記憶装置のように、すべてを区別なく記憶すると、その意味がなくなり、役に立たない情報の雑多な集まりになってしまいます。
rejectText: すべてを忘れることは絶対に悪いことです。すべての知識は忘れることによってのみ生成されるため、何も忘れないのはさらに悪いことです。電気エネルギーを消費するデータ記憶装置のように、ありとあらゆるものを無差別に保存すると、意味を失い、役に立たない情報の無秩序な蓄積となります。
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment: T2 is almost perfect and sounds like human-translated. T1 is almost correct but the way of using punctuation is a little awkward. That is why I chose T2.

source: Ein Gedächtnis, das alles bewahrte, bewahrte im Grunde nichts. Jene Kalifornierin, die sich ohne Mnemotechnik jeden einzelnen Tag seit dem 5. Februar 1980 vergegenwärtigen kann, ist gefangen im Echoraum ihrer fortwährend auf sie einstürzenden Erinnerungen — eine Wiedergängerin jenes attischen Feldherrn Themistokles, der jeden einzelnen Bürger seiner Heimatstadt mit Namen zu nennen wusste und der dem Mnemoniker Simonides ausrichten ließ, eher begehre er die Kunst des Vergessens als die des Gedächtnisses zu erlernen: »Auch was ich nicht in der Erinnerung behalten will, das behalte ich; was ich jedoch vergessen will, das kann ich nicht vergessen.« Eine Vergessenskunst ist aber ein Ding der Unmöglichkeit, weil alle Zeichen Anwesenheiten darstellen, selbst wenn sie auf Abwesenheiten verweisen. Beinahe jeden, den im Römischen Reich der Bann der damnatio memoriae traf, behaupten die Enzyklopädien mit Namen zu kennen.
choiceText: すべてを記憶する記憶力でさえ、実際には何も記憶していないのです。1980年2月5日以来、それぞれの日を記憶術なしで思い出せるカリフォルニアの女性は、彼女に絶えず襲いかかる記憶の中で囚われているのです――アテネの将軍テミストクレスが、自分の故郷のあらゆる市民を名前で呼び分けることができたように、記憶術師シモニデスに伝えた言葉を思い起こします――「記憶を学ぶよりも、忘却の術を学びたい」。しかし、忘却の術は不可能なことなのです、なぜなら、すべての記号は存在を表しているからです。ほとんどの人々は、ローマ帝国において、damnatio memoriae の判決を受けたということを、名前を知っているという事典によって言われています。
rejectText: すべてを保存した記憶は、基本的に何も保存しませんでした。 1980 年 2 月 5 日以来、ニーモニックなしで毎日を視覚化することができたこのカリフォルニア人は、彼女の記憶の反響室に捕らえられ、絶え間なく彼女に衝突しています。彼の故郷の市民であり、覚えるよりも忘れる術を学びたいというニーモニックなシモニデスに次のように語っています。忘れたいものを忘れることはできません」しかし、すべての記号は存在を表しているため、たとえそれらが不在を指していても、忘れることは不可能です。百科事典は、ローマ帝国でdamnatio memoriaeの呪文にかけられたほとんどすべての人を名前で知っていると主張しています.
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment: T2 misses one sentence which is in the original text (»Auch was ich nicht in der Erinnerung behalten will, das behalte ich; was ich jedoch vergessen will, das kann ich nicht vergessen.«) and has a grammatical error is found in the last sentence. However, the translated sentences make sense and the overall quality is much better than T1. T1 lacks important elements such as subjects and the vocabulary ignores the context. It is hard to understand the meaning of each sentence and text as a whole.

source: Der Freitod erscheint vielleicht als die radikalste Maßnahme, über die Ungewissheit der Zukunft zu triumphieren, freilich zum Preis einer verkürzten Existenz. Es wird berichtet, dass zu den Geschenken jener indischen Gesandtschaft, die Augustus einst auf der Insel Samos empfing, nicht nur ein Tiger und ein armloser Jüngling, der seine Füße wie Hände zu benutzen wusste, gehörten, sondern auch ein Mann namens Zarmaros aus der Kaste der Brahmanen, der sein Leben selbst zu beenden gedachte, gerade weil es so verlaufen sei wie gewünscht. Um sicherzustellen, dass ihm nicht doch noch etwas Unvorhergesehenes zustieß, sprang er in Athen lachend, nackt und gesalbt ins Feuer, verbrannte zweifellos qualvoll bei lebendigem Leib und ging mit der Inszenierung seines selbstbestimmten Todes in die Geschichte ein, wenn auch nur als kuriose Anekdote in einem Band jener einst achtzig Bücher umfassenden Römischen Geschichte des Cassius Dio, dessen Inhalt zufällig überliefert wurde. Letztlich ist alles, was noch da ist, schlichtweg das, was übrig geblieben ist.
choiceText: 自殺は、未来の不確実性に勝利するために最も極端な手段として思われるかもしれませんが、それは存在を短縮する代償としてです。とあるインドの使節が、あるとき、サモス島でオーギュストスに贈った贈り物に、虎や腕のない少年がいたという話はよく知られていますが、その他にも、名前がザーマロスで、ブラフマーナーのカースト出身の男性もいたという話があります。彼は、自分の生涯が望んだとおりに進んだので、自らの命を終わらせるつもりだったということです。彼が、何か予期しないことが起こらないようにするために、アテネではしゃぐように、裸で油を塗ったまま、火の中に飛び込んで焼かれるという悲惨な死を選んだのです。その自己決定的な死を演出した彼は、歴史に残ることになりましたが、カッシウス・ディオの『ローマ史八十巻』の一冊に、奇妙なエピソードとして記録されただけです。最後に、残っているものは、単に残っているものだけなのです。
rejectText: 自殺はおそらく、将来の不確実性を克服するための最も急進的な手段のように思われますが、寿命が短くなるという代償はあります。アウグストゥスがかつてサモス島で受け取ったインド大使館の贈り物の中には、トラと、足を手のように使う方法を知っている腕のない若者だけでなく、バラモンのザルマロスというカーストの男もいたと言われています思い通りになったからこそ、自ら命を絶とうと思った人。彼に不測の事態が起こらないことを確認するために、彼はアテネの火事に飛び込み、笑い、裸で油そそがれ、苦しみの中で生きたまま焼かれたことは間違いありません。カッシウス・ディオの80冊のローマ史の巻で、その内容は偶然に受け継がれています。最終的に、残ったものは単に残ったものです。
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment: In T1, there is one phrase which was not translated ("dessen Inhalt zufällig überliefert wurde."), but the translations are accurate otherwise. It also uses less awkward wording. T2 has lots of grammatical errors and lacks verbs and punctuations (e.g., "バラモンのザルマロスというカーストの男" changes the sense, completely, and could be also classified as mistranslation). Furthermore, T2 also has significant omissions; like in "思い通りになったからこそ" it is not clear what "went well" (思い通りになった) as the "life" (人生) is missing.

source: Am Leben zu sein bedeutet, Verluste zu erfahren. Die Frage, was wohl werden wird, dürfte kaum jünger sein als die Menschheit selbst, besteht doch eine so unabdingbare wie beunruhigende Eigenschaft der Zukunft darin, dass sie sich der Vorhersehbarkeit entzieht und damit auch Zeitpunkt und Umstände des Todes im Dunkeln lässt. Wer kennt nicht den Abwehrzauber des süßbittren Vorausleidens, den fatalen Drang, das Befürchtete durch gedankliche Vorwegnahme verhindern zu wollen? Man ahnt die Verheerungen voraus, imaginiert mögliche Katastrophen und wähnt sich so vor bösen Überraschungen gefeit. In der Antike versprachen die Träume Trost, sagten die Griechen ihnen doch nach, sie verhießen, Orakeln gleich, das Kommende und nähmen somit der Zukunft zwar nicht das Unabänderliche, wohl aber den Schrecken des Unerwarteten. Nicht wenige nehmen sich aus Angst vor dem Tod das Leben.
choiceText: 生きているということは、損失を経験することを意味します。何が起こるかという問いは、人類自体よりもはるかに古いものではないでしょうか。未来には、不可欠でありながら不安を覚えさせる特性があります。それは、予測不可能であり、それ故に死の瞬間と状況が暗闇の中に隠されているということです。甘く苦い先行苦痛を防衛する魔法を知らないでしょうか。運命的な動機、想像しうる災害を予測し、そうして悪い驚きを防ぐことを望む欲求はないでしょうか。古代では、夢が慰めを約束してくれると言われていました。ギリシャ人は夢が、オラクルのように将来を約束すると言っていました。未来を変えることはできませんが、驚きを取り除くことはできました。死を恐れて、自殺を図る人も少なくありません。
rejectText: 生きているということは、損失を経験することを意味します。何が起こるかという問題は、人類そのものほど若いわけではありません。なぜなら、予測可能性を逃れ、死の時間と状況を暗闇に残すことは、未来の不可欠で不安な特徴だからです。ほろ苦い期待の防御魔法、精神的な期待によって恐れられていることを防ぎたいという致命的な衝動を知らない人はいますか?荒廃を予測し、起こりうる大惨事を想像し、したがって、自分は厄介な驚きに免疫があると信じています.古代において、夢は慰めを約束しました。ギリシャ人が神託のように来るべきことを約束したと言いました。死を恐れて自ら命を絶つ人も少なくありません。
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment: T1 has one error in grammar, but it looks good otherwise. T2 has several grammatical errors and lacks some phrases in the original text. Sometimes the connecting elements such as particles （の、が、）are missing.

source: Vielfältig sind die Strategien, Vergangenes festzuhalten und dem Vergessen Einhalt zu gebieten. Traut man der Überlieferung, steht am Anfang unserer Geschichtsschreibung eine Reihe vernichtender Kriege zwischen Persern und Griechen und am Beginn der heute beinahe vergessenen Gedächtniskunst ein Unglück mit vielen Toten: Es war in Thessalien, wo im frühen vorchristlichen 5. Jahrhundert ein einstürzendes Haus eine ganze Festtagsgesellschaft unter sich begrub und es dem einzigen Uberlebenden, dem Dichter Simonides von Keos, dank seines geschulten Gedächtnisses gelang, das zerstörte Gebäude im Geiste erneut zu betreten und die Sitzordnung der Gäste aufzurufen, woraufhin sich die von den Trümmern entstellten Leichen identifizieren ließen. Es gehört zu den zahlreichen Paradoxien, die dem Entweder-oder von Tod und Leben innewohnen, dass, indem der Verstorbene als etwas unwiederbringlich Verlorenes benannt wird, sich die Trauer über seinen Verlust zugleich verdoppelt und halbiert, wohingegen das im Unklaren liegende Schicksal eines Vermissten oder Verschollenen die Angehörigen in einem diffusen Alptraum aus banger Hoffnung und verwehrter Trauer gefangenhält, der sowohl Aufarbeitung als auch Weiterleben verhindert.
choiceText: 過去を保持し、忘却を阻止するための戦略は多岐にわたります。伝承を信じるなら、私たちの歴史書きのはじまりは、ペルシャ人とギリシャ人の間で繰り広げられた破壊的な戦争の連続であり、今ではほとんど忘れられてしまった記憶術の始まりは、多くの死者をもたらした不幸な出来事でした。それは、キリスト前5世紀のテッサリアで起こったもので、崩れた家が多くの祝祭者を埋めてしまったとき、唯一の生き残りである詩人のシモニデス・フォン・ケオスが、訓練された記憶力によって、再びその家を心の中で踏み入れ、客の座席順を叫び出し、そのとき崩れた建物で歪んだ死体を識別できたのです。死と生の二者択一のパラドックスのなかには、故人を失われたものとして名づけることで、その死の痛みが同時に倍増し、半減するというものもあります。一方、行方不明者や失踪者の運命が不明瞭なとき、家族は不安と望みをかき乱された不確定な悪夢に閉じ込められ、解決も先に進むこともできなくなります。
rejectText: 過去にしがみつき、忘却を止めるためのさまざまな戦略があります。伝統を信頼するなら、ペルシア人とギリシア人との間の一連の壊滅的な戦争は、私たちの歴史記述の始まりであり、今ではほとんど忘れ去られている記憶術の始まりには、多くの死者を出した災害があります。それはテッサリアでした。紀元前 5 世紀初頭、倒壊した家屋がホリデー パーティー全体を殺しました。唯一の生存者である詩人シオスのシモニデスは、訓練された記憶力のおかげで、廃墟となった建物に精神的に再び入り込み、ゲストの座席配置を呼び出すことができました。がれきによって変形した死体が確認された。生と死のどちらか、またはどちらかに固有の多くのパラドックスの 1 つであるのは、故人を回復不能な失われたものと名付けることによって、彼を失った悲しみが同時に 2 倍になったり半分になったりするのに対し、行方不明者や行方不明者の不確かな運命が親族を引き留めていることです。不安な希望と否定された悲しみの漠然とした悪夢に囚われており、それがそれを受け入れることと生き続けることの両方を妨げています。
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment: Both T1 and T2 translated all the sentences in the original text. T1 has some errors in vocabulary translation, which don't match with the context and is very literal at times. The quality of T2 is much better than T1 (the only issue being "キリスト前" which is understandable, but would be usually referred to as "キリスト紀元前"). It is more dynamic and uses better phrasing (e.g., "多くの死者を出した災害があります" (T1) vs "多くの死者をもたらした不幸な出来事でした" (T2)). T2 is also better at dividing and connecting sentences while T1 makes it really hard to understand, there is no good flow to it.

source: Die Zäsur des Todes ist der Ausgangspunkt von Erbe und Erinnerung und die Totenklage die Quelle jeder Kultur, mit der man die nun klaffende Leerstelle, die plötzliche Stille mit Gesängen, Gebeten und Geschichten füllt, in denen das Abwesende noch einmal verlebendigt wird. Wie eine Hohlform lässt die Erfahrung des Verlusts die Umrisse dessen, was zu beklagen ist, hervortreten, und nicht selten verwandelt es sich im verklärenden Licht der Trauer zu einem Objekt der Begierde, oder wie es ein Heidelberger Professor für Zoologie im Vorwort eines Bändchens der Neuen Brehm-Bücherei formuliert: »Es scheint zu den rational kaum fassbaren Eigenschaften des westlichen Menschen zu gehören, dass er Verlorenes höher bewertet als noch Bestehendes, anders ist die merkwürdige Faszination nicht zu erklären, die seither vom Beutelwolf ausgeht.«
choiceText: 死の境界線は、遺産と記憶の出発点であり、喪葬は文化の元であり、それによって、急に開いた空白、突然の静けさを、歌、祈り、物語で埋めることができます。そして、悲しむべきものの形が浮き彫りになり、悲しみの輝きの中で、欲望の対象となることもしばしばあります。また、ハイデルベルクのゾオロジーの教授が、『ニューブレム・ビューチェーリー』の小冊子の前文で述べているように、「西洋人が失われたものを、まだ残っているものよりも高く評価するというのは、理性的にはほとんど理解できない特性の一つであるように思われる。そうしないと、毛皮狼が今日までもつづく奇妙な魅力を説明できない。」
rejectText: 死のカエスラは継承と記憶の出発点であり、喪はすべての文化の源であり、それによって人はギャップのある空白、突然の静けさを歌、祈り、そして欠けているものに命を吹き込む物語で埋めます。また。喪失の経験は、喪に服すべきものの輪郭を中空の形のように浮かび上がらせ、それが喪の変容する光の中で欲望の対象に変わること、またはハイデルベルクの動物学教授が言ったように、それが珍しいことではありませんノイエ・ブレーム・ブッヘーライの巻の序文で次のように述べている: »西側の人々のほとんど理解できない特徴の 1 つは、彼らがまだそこにあるものよりも失われたものを高く評価することのようです. 他に方法はありません.それ以来、Thylacine から発せられてきた奇妙な魅力を説明するために. «
difficult_choice: NO, the translations I have chosen is visibly better.
comment:
T1 leave lots of punctuations and brackets in German style as they are. And T1 ignores how each element works in a sentence: subject, object, adverb etc. Especially at the end each part is being translated on its own forming an incomprehensible whole (technically, "他に方法はありません" is there in the source, but without it being connected to other parts of the sentence it just doesn't convey the same meaning). 
T2 does not translate some elements which are in the original texts, but the translated sentences make sense.
